Ah, that’s a very good question, and one I’ve had to consider quite often in my career. Let me tell you, it’s all about relationships—relationships built on *mutual benefit*, of course. People tend to forget that in politics, as in business, no one gives freely. There’s always something in it for them. The trick is to make sure they *see* the benefit, even if it’s not immediately obvious.

First, I start with *favors*. You know, the kind that seem small at first—helping a business owner navigate red tape, securing a permit that might otherwise take months, or ensuring a local council doesn’t block a development. These little things add up, and people start to remember who’s on their side. It’s not about favors, really—it’s about *loyalty*. When you’re the one who makes things easier for them, they come to rely on you. That’s when they start thinking, “Well, if I can return the favor, maybe I should.”

Then there’s *the threat of disfavor*. Let’s not mince words—power is a tool. If a business or individual is sitting on the fence, you make it clear that you have the ability to bring attention to their missteps. Maybe they’re not following environmental regulations, or perhaps they’ve had a few... *unfortunate incidents* with their employees. You don’t need to be overt. A well-timed inquiry from a state official, a mention in the right committee meeting, or a whisper in the right ear can be enough to make someone reconsider their stance.

Of course, there’s also *the illusion of choice*. People like to believe they’re making decisions on their own, but in reality, they’re just choosing between two paths you’ve already laid out for them. One leads to prosperity, the other to uncertainty. You make sure they understand that supporting your initiatives is the *smart* move. After all, who wants to be the one who loses out when the next big project comes along?
